Research article Investigation of the bifunctionality of catalysts based on Rh associated with an oxophilic promoter in the hydrogenolysis of tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol to 1,5-pentanediol Clément Gondre Data curation Formal analysis Investigation Validation Visualization Valérie Meille Data curation Formal analysis Investigation Methodology Madjid Ouali Investigation Formal analysis Georgeta Postole Data curation Methodology Investigation Stéphane Loridant Formal analysis Investigation Writing – review & editing Methodology Catherine Pinel Funding acquisition Resources Supervision Writing – review & editing Project administration Noémie Perret Conceptualization Resources Supervision Validation Writing – original draft Methodology Project administration ⁎ Univ Lyon, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, CNRS, IRCELYON, 69626 Villeurbanne, France Univ Lyon Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1 CNRS IRCELYON 69626 Villeurbanne France Univ Lyon, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, CNRS, IRCELYON, 69626 Villeurbanne, France ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The hydrogenolysis of tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol was studied in aqueous phase over a range of bifunctional catalysts based on Rh and an oxophilic promoter (Re, W, Mo) supported on ZrO2. The structures of the catalysts were characterised employing powder XRD, Raman spectroscopy and TEM analysis. The degrees of reduction were evaluated by H2-TPR and XPS analyses. The metallic properties were assessed by CO chemisorption. For the first time, the acidic properties were evaluated in aqueous phase by calorimetric measurements of 2-phenyl-ethylamine adsorption heat. The combination of metallic Rh sites and Brønsted sites (linked to the oxophilic metal on ZrO2) is crucial for the reaction. The bifunctionality of the catalysts was demonstrated and up to 81% yield of 1,5-pentanediol is obtained with 5%Rh-4%Mo/ZrO2. Keywords Tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol Bifunctional catalysts Pentanediol Acidity Microcalorimetry Aqueous phase ZrO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The valorization of lignocellulosic biomass through catalytic systems is an interesting approach for the sustainable production of chemicals. In this context, furfural has been identified as one of the key platform molecules [1]. Furfural is industrially obtained through the dehydration of C5 monomer (e.g. xylose) which results from the acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of C5 fraction of hemicellulose (e.g. xylan) with H2SO4 [2]. It is then hydrogenated to furfuryl alcohol, in gas phase, employing a copper catalyst. Finally, tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) is produced commercially by catalytic hydrogenation of furfuryl alcohol with a Ni based catalyst [2–4]. Terminal-diols are used as monomers for the production of polyesters with applications such as adhesives, elastomers and coatings. 1,6-hexanediol is widely used; however, it is commercially produced from benzene, as a by-product during caprolactam production. Hence, there is a growing interest on the development of biomass-derived monomers. 1,5-propanediol has been proposed as a promising alternative [5]. Coatings based on 1,5-propanediol have been shown to exhibit properties (e.g. hardness, flexibility, adhesion strength) similar to those based on 1,6-hexanediol [5]. The selective C-O hydrogenolysis of cyclic ethers to the corresponding α,ω-diols is a reaction of great interest. It is known that the hydrogenolysis of THFA can generate 1,5-pentanediol and 1,2-pentanediol (Scheme 1 ). The latter tends to be formed more preferably over conventional monometallic catalysts (e.g. Rh/SiO2, Ir/SiO2) [6–8]. Through a series of studies, Tomishige et al. have shown that the addition of an oxophilic metal greatly increased the activity of the catalyst and the selectivity towards 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PDO) [8–12]. Since, a wide range of bimetallic M1-M2 systems have been tested for this reaction, with M1 = Rh [7–11,13–15], Ir [7,16–18], Pt [7,16,19], Pd [7,16], Ru [7,16], Ni [20]. It has been shown that catalysts based on Rh and Ir usually exhibit the highest activity, in comparison to other noble metals (Pt, Pd, Ru) [7,16,17] or non-noble metals (Ni, Co) [7]. Catalysts based on Ru promote mainly the formation of tetrahydrofuran and 2-methyltetrahydrofuran [7,16]. Non-noble metal catalysts, such as Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/SiO2, have been tested, but harsh conditions were employed (250 °C) and small conversions were obtained (<20%) [21,22]. Interesting results were obtained recently with Ni-PrOx/Al2O3 (1,5-PDO yield of 70%) [23] or Ni/Ln(OH)3 (1,5-PDO yield of 88%) [24], however the reactions have been conducted using 2-propanol as solvent at 150–200 °C and under 30–60 bar of H2. With noble metal-based catalysts, the reactions are usually performed with water as solvent and under milder conditions of temperature (80–150 °C) and pressure (34–80 bar). Re [8–11,13,15,16,18], W [9,16,19] and Mo [7,9,11,14,16] are often used as the second metal (M2), and to a lesser extent V [16,17], Nb [16] and Pr [23]. The activity of the catalyst was shown to follow the order: Re > Mo > W for Ir-M2/SiO2 and Rh-M2/SiO2 [9,12]. This order can change depending on the cyclic ester used as substrate [12]. Different supports have been tested including SiO2 [7–11,14,17,19], C [7,13,15,16], ZrO2 [19] , TiO2 [18,19], Al2O3 [19,23], SiO2-Al2O3 [7], H-ZSM-5 [7]. It seems that the presence of weak acid sites on the support does not affect the catalytic results, however the presence of strong acid sites promotes the ring closure of 1,5-PDO towards tetrahydropyran [20,22]. The highest yields of 1,5-PDO reported in the literature are in the range of 83% to 94% employing bimetallic catalysts M1-M2 supported on SiO2 or C, with M1 = Rh or Ir, and M2 = W, Mo, Re [8,9,12,15]. It was shown that the formation 1,5-PDO results from the synergistic effect between the two metals (Ir-Mo [7]; Rh-Re [10]). It has been proposed that THFA is adsorbed via the OH group on active sites linked to the oxophilic metal (M2). Then the hydrogenolysis of the C-O is catalyzed by the noble metal (M1) [10,13,19]. Physical mixtures of a noble metal and an oxophilic metal are less active, thus a close chemical contact and a strong metal-oxide interaction are crucial [7,11]. The formation of an alloy or a core–shell structure (where the core consists of ReOx clusters and the shell Rh metal particles) was also proposed [8,13]. Work to date has largely focused on SiO2 and C as supports for the hydrogenolysis of THFA and we could not find any report in the literature that provides an investigation of Rh-M2/ZrO2, with M2 = W, Mo, Re. However, we previously reported the hydrogenolysis of polyols over Rh-Re catalysts [25–27]. The production of linear deoxygenated C4, C5 and C6 products was achieved (with selectivity in the range of 54–71%) by hydrogenolysis of erythritol, xylitol and sorbitol over supported Rh-ReOx catalyst, respectively [25,26]. The effects of temperature (150–240 °C), pressure (30–80 bar) and support (TiO2, ZrO2, SiO2) were investigated. The highest selectivity was obtained at 200 °C, under 80 bar with ZrO2 as support. This catalytic process was then successfully applied for the hydrogenolysis of sugars and hemicellulose-extracted liquor from delignified maritime pine [27]. We observed that SiO2 was not stable under the hydrothermal conditions employed and Si was detected in the final solution. So, we moved towards ZrO2, which is stable in water at high temperature, and higher conversion were obtained. In the same manner, Feng et al. [19] reported much higher yield of 1,5-PDO over Pt-WO3/ZrO2 than Pt-WO3/SiO2. Tungsten, molybdenum and rhenium catalysts supported on ZrO2 are known to exhibit acidity, which depends notably on the metal loading, the pre-treatment of the catalyst, the nature of surface species, and the support [28,29]. In the current work, we report for the first time the evaluation of a range of bimetallic catalysts supported on ZrO2 for the hydrogenolysis of THFA towards 1,5-PDO. We focused our study on the influence of the nature of the second metal (Rh-Re, Rh-W, Rh-Mo) and the metal ratio on the catalytic results. In literature, the optimal metal content for Pt, Rh and Ir is 4% by weight [7,10–12,17]. Thus, metal loadings between 1.5 and 5% were used to study this parameter. The presence of water can drastically modify the acidity of the catalysts [30]. Therefore, we studied the acidity of the bifunctional catalysts by microcalorimetry in the presence of water. Finally, a kinetic study was conducted with the best catalyst. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Rh-MOx/ZrO2 (M = Re, Mo, W) were prepared by consecutive aqueous impregnations. In a 250 mL flask, ca. 5 g of ZrO2 (Luxfer MEL Technologies XZO 632/18) was suspended in 45 mL of ultra-pure water. An aqueous solution of RhCl3 (7.6 g L−1) was added dropwise to the solution. The mixture was stirred for 7 h at room temperature. After removal of the water, the material was dried overnight in an oven at 80 °C under N2 and crushed. The resulting powder was calcined under air (60 mL min−1, 4.2 °C min−1 to 500 °C for 3 h). The second impregnation was conducted as previously, employing an aqueous solution of either NH4ReO4 (10.0 g L−1), (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (10.9 g L−1) or (NH4)10H2(W2O7)6·xH2O (7.8 g L−1). After calcination at 500 °C, the materials were reduced under H2 (60 mL min−1, 4.2 °C min−1 to maximal temperature for 3 h) at either 100 °C, 450 °C or 700 °C. After flushing with Ar, the catalysts were passivated under 1% v/v O2/N2 (30 mL min−1, 30 min, room temperature). The samples reduced at 450 °C are denoted Rh-M (with M = Re, Mo, W). The samples reduced at 100 °C and 700 °C are denoted Rh-M−100 and Rh-M−700, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of the catalysts were recorded with a Bruker D8-Advance diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.54184 Å). Catalysts were analyzed with a step of 0.02° and 0.5 s of counting per point, over the range 10° ≤ 2θ ° ≤ 80°. Phase identification was performed using the DiffracSuite Eva software (Bruker) and the JCPDS-ICDD-PDF4 + database. Mean crystallite sizes (±1 nm) and phases quantification (±1 wt%) were obtained by performing Rietveld refinements using Topas 5 software. The metal contents of the catalysts were determined using an ACTIVA ICP-OES instrument (Horiba). Before analysis, the samples were mineralized by dissolution with a mixture of HNO3, H2SO4 and HF, and then heated overnight at 100 °C in closed vials. The values are reported with an absolute accuracy of ± 0.1%. Surface areas (SA) of the samples were determined from N2 physisorption at − 196 °C using an ASAP 2020 Micromeritics apparatus, employing the BET method. Before the measurements, the catalysts were desorbed at 150 °C for 3 h under high vacuum (10−4 mbar). The values are reported with an absolute accuracy of ± 5 m2 g−1. Scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) images were obtained with a TITAN ETEM instrument operated at 80–300 kV, equipped with an X-MAX SDD energy-dispersive Xray spectroscopy (EDX) detector from Oxford-Instrument and a Tridiem ERs GIF from Gatan. The samples were deposited on copper-coated grids. Particles size distributions were obtained measuring at least 150 particles, using Fiji software. A heat flow reaction calorimeter with differential configuration and equipped with a magnetic stirring system (TITRYS, from Setaram) was used to measure the liquid–solid adsorption heats over different catalysts. The reference contained pure solvent (1.5 mL) and the measurement cell contained the solvent and the solid sample (ca. 200 mg). A programmable syringe pump (PH 2000, Harvard Apparatus) was linked to the calorimeter by capillary tubes. Using this syringe pump, successive pulse injections of dosed amounts (0.3 mL) of a solution of the probe in the solvent (0.03 mol/L) were sent onto the sample maintained at 30 °C at 2 h time intervals. A preheating furnace allowed the injection of the probe solution at the same temperature of 30 °C. The effective acidities of the solids were determined by using 2-phenyl-ethylamine as basic probe (PEA, pKa = 9.84) and deionized water as solvent (polarity = 2.95 D). The surface chemical composition and oxidation states of Rh, Re, W and Mo in the samples were analyzed by XPS using a commercial AXIS Ultra DLD KRATOS with a monochromatized AlKα source (1486.6 eV). C 1 s, Zr 3d, Rh 3d, Re 4f, W 4f and Mo 3d core levels were fitted using a combination of Voigt line shapes. The binding energies (±0.5 eV) were referred to the C1 s line set at BE = 284.8 eV. The distributions of oxidation states are given with an absolute accuracy of ± 2 %. Raman spectra were recorded using a LabRam HR Evolution spectrometer (Horiba) equipped with a CCD detector. Measurements were carried out under a microscope with a 50x objective that focuses the laser beam on the sample surface and collects the scattered light. The exciting line at 532 nm was used with a power limited at 100 microW. The time of acquisition was adjusted according to the intensity of the Raman scattering. It was previously checked that the samples laser heating was negligible with such power. The wavenumber values obtained from the spectra are accurate to within 4 cm−1. The material obtained after impregnation and calcination at 500 °C is placed in a cellule Linkam under flowing gases. The sample is first analyzed at room temperature (spectrum (1)) then treated under N2 (50 mL min−1, 50 °C min−1 to 450 °C for 1 h). After cooling down, the spectrum (2) was recorded, at ca. 100 °C. The sample was then reduced under H2/N2 (40/40 mL min−1, 4 °C min−1 to 450 °C for 3 h). After cooling down, the spectrum (3) was recorded, at ca. 100 °C. A final spectrum (4) was recorded at room temperature after passivation under O2/N2 (1.7/104 mL min−1, 30 min, room temperature). CO chemisorption was performed by using a 3 Flex instrument (Micromeritics). Before the CO uptake measurements, the samples were reduced at 450 °C under H2 for 4 h and evacuated under vacuum at 300 °C for 4 h. CO uptake was measured at 35 °C. Rh particle sizes, dCO (±0.3 nm) were calculated based on COchem (µmolCO g−1; ± 5 %) considering a CO/Rh molar ratio of 1. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) were conducted using a Thermo Scientific TPDRO 1100. Samples (ca. 200 mg) were loaded into a quartz cell and pre-treated under a 40 mL min−1 flow of 5% O2/He at 3 °C min−1 until 500 °C. The samples were cooled down and flushed with Ar. Then, a flow of 40 mL min−1 of 5% v/v H2/Ar was passed through the samples, and the temperature was increased at 4 °C min−1 from 30 to 900 °C. The effluent gas passed through a liquid N2 trap, and changes in H2 consumption were monitored by TCD. The amount of H2 consumed during TPR (μmol g−1) are based on the integration of the peak between 25 °C and 450 °C and given with a precision of 2 %. 2.3 Catalytic study THFA was purchased from Alfa Aesar (purity 98%). The experiments were performed in a 300 mL batch Hastelloy Parr 4560 autoclave equipped with a magnetically driven impeller and a liquid sampling system. For standard condition, 6 g of THFA were dissolved in 114 g of water. This solution (5 wt%; 500 mmolTHFA L−1) and 1 g of catalyst were loaded into the reactor. For generating kinetic data, some reactions were conducted with 1–3 g of THFA and/or 0.3 g of catalyst. After sealing, the autoclave was purged three times with Ar and heated to the desired reaction temperature (90–120 °C). The reactor was then pressurized with H2 (20–80 bar) and stirred (900 rpm). The addition of H2 corresponds to the start of the reaction (t = 0 h). To follow the evolution of the reactions, 1 mL of solution were collected periodically and analyzed by GC. After 24 h, the reactor was cooled down and the pressure was released. The reaction mixture was filtered and the catalyst was dried. TOC (Total Organic Compound) of the solutions at the end of the reaction (after cooling down to room temperature) were measured with a Shimadzu TOC-VCSH analyzer in order to determine the carbon balance, hence the possible formation of gaseous products. The values are also compared to the theoretical carbon balance in the liquid phase quantified by GC in order to evaluate any possible shortfall of carbon amount. The concentration of THFA, 2-methyltetrahydrofuran, 1,2-pentanediol, 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PDO), 2-pentanol, 1-pentanol (POL) and 1-butanol (POL) were determined using a GC Agilent Technologies 6890 N with a flame ionization detector employing a VF-WAXms column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). The temperature was increased up to 190 °C, under helium as carrier gas. The conversions were evaluated based on the initial concentration of THFA and defined by, (1) C o n v e r s i o n % = C 0 sTHFA - C t THFA C 0 THFA × 100 where C 0 THFA and C t THFA refer to the concentration of THFA initial and at time t, respectively. (2) S e l e c t i v i t y % = C t i × N C i C 0 THFA - C t THFA × N C THFA × 100 With C t i , the concentration of product i at time t; N C i and N C THFA the number of carbon atoms in product i and THFA, respectively. The initial reaction rate was calculated based on the slope of the linear curve at low conversion (<40%) and the mass of Rh: (3) V Rh ( mmol THFA g Rh - 1 h - 1 ) = n THFA m Rh × t The initial rates of reaction were also expressed per total mass of catalyst (Vcat; mmolTHFA gcata h−1) or per mass of the second metal M (VM; mmolTHFA gM −1 h−1). The productivity corresponds to the amount of 1,5-PDO formed at the end of the reaction per mass of catalyst (mmolPDO gcata −1). Repeated reactions delivered conversion and products yield reproducible within ± 2 %. The effect of the stirring rate was examined, and there was no effect, i.e. no diffusion limitation, when working above 600 rpm. The standard condition was set at 900 rpm. The experimental data points of the concentrations of THFA, 1,5-PDO, POL and BOL were fitted using the version 4.27 of COPASI (COmplex PAthway SImulator), available at https://copasi.org/ [31]. The rates constants (ki, i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) were estimated by solving the equations (presented in section 3.3. Kinetic study) using the genetic algorithm; the objective function being a weighted sum of squares (mean square weight). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of Rh-MOx (M = Re, W, Mo) catalysts Series of monometallic Rh/ZrO2 and bimetallic Rh-MOx/ZrO2 (M = Re, W, Mo) catalysts were prepared by successive impregnation, followed by calcination at 500 °C, reduction at 450 °C and passivation at room temperature. The loadings of rhodium (1.5–5%) and of the second metal (0–4%) were varied; the name of the catalysts a%Rh-b%M reflects the theoretical metal loadings (a,b) which are very close to the those obtained by ICP (Table S1). The metals mass and molar ratios are included in Table S1 and ranged from 0.2 to 3.4 gM/gRh (equivalent to 0.1–3.7 molM/molRh). The samples 5%Rh, 5%Rh-4%Re, 5%Rh-4%W and 5%Rh-4%Mo were chosen as representative catalysts. Their specific surfaces areas are similar (113 ± 4 m2 g−1, Table S2) and consistent with the bare support (114 m2 g−1). The XRD diffractograms of the 4 catalysts and ZrO2 are included Figure S1. The diffractogram of the other catalysts are included in Figure S2 (Rh), Figure S3 (Rh-Re), Figure S4 (Rh-W) and Figure S5 (Rh-Mo). The XRD diffractograms show the characteristic peaks of ZrO2 monoclinic (ICDD file 00–037-1484) and tetragonal (ICDD file 00–050-1089) phases. The main peak associated with Rh fcc phase (ICDD file 00–005-0685) at ca. 41.0° is hidden by a peak of ZrO2 while the second main peak at 47.8° (I = 50%) could not be detected for any catalysts. Similarly, regarding the second metal, we could not observe any peaks attributed to either the metals (Re, W, Mo) or oxides (e.g. Re2O7, WOx, MoOx) crystalline phases. These results suggest the presence of small nanoparticles. Rietveld refinements show that the ZrO2 phases are stable after the syntheses and thermal treatments of the catalysts. Indeed, the crystallite sizes of the monoclinic (10 nm) and tetragonal (6 nm) phases as well as the monoclinic/tetragonal ratio (90%/10%) remain the same for the catalysts and the support (Table S2). In order to investigate the effect of the reduction temperature, three samples of these bimetallic catalysts (5%Rh-4%M) were reduced at 100 °C and 700 °C instead of 450 °C. For the samples reduced at 100 °C (Rh-M−100, Figure S6) no changes were observed in comparison to those reduced at 450 °C. For the samples reduced at 700 °C (Rh-M−700, Figure S6), the tetragonal phase is partially transformed to monoclinic phase. Hence, the monoclinic/tetragonal ratio increases from 90%/10% up to 96%/4% (Table S2). There is also an increase in the crystallite sizes, especially regarding the monoclinic phase, which is associated with a decrease in the surface area down to 40 m2 g−1. These phenomena are in agreement with the literature, as the transformation from tetragonal to monoclinic phase is known to occur around 600 °C, and it is usually associated with a decrease in surface area [32]. It seems that the presence of the second metal stabilizes slightly the support, following the order: Mo > W > Re. The samples were analyzed by Raman spectroscopy. As representative example, the results associated with 5%Rh-4%Mo are presented in Fig. 1 . The spectrum S-1 corresponds to the sample after ex situ calcination at 500 °C. Since hydration of supported MoOx samples by exposure to ambient moisture can alter Raman spectra [33,34], the material was pre-treated in situ under N2 (spectrum S-2). The sample was then reduced at 450 °C (spectrum S-3), and passivated (spectrum S-4). For comparison, a supplementary sample was synthesized and analyzed: A monometallic 4%Mo/ZrO2 was also made by impregnation and calcined at 500 °C. The support ZrO2, monometallic 5%Rh/ZrO2 and 4%Mo/ZrO2 are included in Fig. S7a for comparison. The support presents bands in the 150–700 cm−1 region. The bands at 178, 215, 325, 377, 470, 552 and 628 cm−1 can be assigned to the monoclinic ZrO2 phase [35,36]. Due to the low amount of tetragonal ZrO2 phase, no bands associated with this phase was detected (e.g. 149, 269, 319, 462, 603 and 649 cm−1) [36,37]. The band at 1044 cm−1 is due to the presence of carbonates (ν1 stretching vibration) in the support, which disappears after impregnation of the metals and calcination. For all the catalysts presented in Fig. 1, supplementary bands were observed in the region of 700–1000 cm−1 and associated with molybdenum species [34]. Supported molybdenum oxides can exist as MoOx monomers, two dimensional polymolybdates and crystalline phases. An intense and broad band is observed at 844 cm−1 in the spectrum S-1 recorded in ambient air as well as another one at 978 cm−1, much weaker. They do not correspond to crystalline MoO3, MoO2, ZrMo2O8, Rh2O3 (Table S3). They are also different to those observed for 4%Mo sample at 855 and 947 cm-1 in ambient air (Fig. S7a) attributed to ν(Mo = O) and ν (Mo-O-Mo) of polymolybdate Mo6+ species with structure close to hepta and octamolybdate species [34,38–40]. The presence of [RhMo6O24H6]3− Anderson-type heteropolyoxomolybdate can be also ruled out since its main bands are located at 216, 357, 549, 896, 949 cm−1 [41]. However, an intense band around 840 cm−1 was observed for MoOx species reduced by methanol [42] or reduced Mo5O14 type species [43]. Therefore, the two bands of Rh-MoO3/ZrO2 at 844 and 978 cm−1 (spectrum S-1) are attributed to the presence of partially reduced molybdates species at the surface of ZrO2. It implies reduction of Mo6+ cations upon the second calcination step. After treatment under N2 (spectrum 2), the ν (Mo-O) band is shifted to slightly higher frequencies (986 cm−1) due to the dehydration of the samples, hence removal of physisorbed H2O and shortening of Mo = O bonds [33,34]. As expected, after reduction (spectrum 3), the characteristic bands of MoOx species disappear. After passivation (spectrum 4), two bands at 874 and 972 cm−1 are visible and still attributed to the presence of partially reduced molybdates at the surface. For comparison, the spectra associated with 5%Rh, 5%Rh-4%Re and 5%Rh-4%W, after reduction and passivation, are included in Figure S7. As expected, all the bands present in the spectrum of 5%Rh/ZrO2 can be attributed to the support which suggest that the rhodium is reduced. However, it is difficult completely to rule out the presence of Rh2O3 as the characteristics bands (277, 284, 426, 572, 614 cm−1) [44,45] could be hindered by the support. The spectrum associated with 5%Rh-4%Re presents a large band around 875–946 cm−1 and a band at 985 cm−1 which can be associated with rhenium oxide species. Indeed, Wachs et al. [46] observed a band at 970 cm−1 along with a broad band centered around 920 cm−1 for 5%Re/ZrO2 (calcined at 450 °C) that they attributed to surface rhenium oxide species with isolated ReO4 structure because closely matching the Raman bands of the [ReO4]− perrhenate ion in aqueous solution [46]. Finally, the spectrum of 5%Rh-4%W presents a wide band around 915 cm−1 associated with WO4 monotungstate or polytungstate species of low nuclearity [47,48]. We can definitively exclude the presence of crystalline γ-WO3 which would have characteristic bands around 800 and 710 cm−1 [48,49]. To conclude, Raman analysis shows that the Rh is reduced, while the second metal is present as non-crystalline small clusters of MOx (M = Re, W, Mo) partially reduced in the case of Mo. CO chemisorption was measured on selected samples and the results are included in Table 1 . There are three main types of CO species adsorbed on rhodium: gem-dicarbonyl (2CO-Rh+), monocarbonyl species with CO occupying a single surface site (CO-Rh) and bridged carbonyl species (CO-2Rh) with CO between two adjacent metal atoms in the surface [50,51]. The gem-dicarbonyl species tend to form on the edge atoms of supported Rh rafts. Dicarbonyl species usually occur on small particles (particles with diameters ≤ 1.5 nm) while monocarbonyl species predominates on metal particles with sizes ≥ 2 nm [52,53]. Bridged and dentate interactions might occur when rhodium particles adjoin each other. Rh particle sizes were estimated employing a one-to-one chemisorption stoichiometry to Rh (CO/Rh molar ratio of 1). Based on the results, the particle sizes are around 2 nm for the monometallic Rh/ZrO2, suggesting the predominant presence of monocarbonyl species [52] . A slight decrease in CO/Rh ratio was observed when loading was modified from 3% to 5% Rh corresponding to a slight increase in particle size from 2.1 up to 2.6 nm (entries 1, 2). After incorporation of a second metal, CO/Rh decreases. It was previously reported that the amount of linearly adsorbed CO decreases, after addition of an oxophilic promoter (e.g. Fe, Mo, Re), as part of the Rh is covered and inaccessible [8,9,11,51]. For a constant Rh loading, it can be seen that CO/Rh decreases as the amount of Mo increases (entries 1, 5, 6, 7). So, Mo atoms cover the Rh nanoparticles and prevent CO adsorption. It is worth noting that CO/Rh is the same for 3%Rh-4%Mo and 5%Rh-4%Mo suggesting similar number of metallic active sites per mol of Rh. The second metal must be in close proximity of Rh in order to decrease CO chemisorption. Furthermore, we evaluated the influence of the nature of the second metal on the CO chemisorption using the same weight ratio (5% Rh-4%M). As expected, whatever, the nature of the second metal, CO/Rh ratio is lowered for the bimetallic compared to the monometallic catalyst (entries 2, 3, 4, 8). It can be noted that the decrease in chemisorbed CO was more pronounced with Mo compared to Re or W. This could be attributed to a closer proximity between the two metals and/or the fact that molecular weight of Mo is lower than Re or W giving higher coverage of Rh particles (nMo/nRh = 0.8 > nRe/nRh ≈ nW/nRh ≈ 0.5, Table S1). Based on CO/Rh, we can suppose that the metal–metal interaction follows the order: Rh-Mo > Rh-W > Rh-Re. The STEM pictures of 5%Rh-4%W and 5%Rh-4%Mo (Fig. 2 ) show that the catalysts exhibit small nanoparticles on the surface of the support with an average diameter of 1.7 nm and 1.5 nm, respectively (Figures S8 and S10). The results associated with 5%Rh-4%Re were already presented elsewhere [25]. These analyses are consistent with the particle size estimated by CO chemisorption for Rh/ZrO2 (2 nm) which confirm that the decrease in CO chemisorption after incorporation of the second metal is due to a blockage of the Rh sites, and it is not attributed to an increase in the particle size. Mapping EDX analyses (Figures S9 and S11) revealed that (W, Rh) and (Mo, Rh) are present and dispersed on the surface. Moreover, local EDX analyses (Figures S9 and S11, 3 nm probe) suggest that the two metals are present in the same area. In order to assess the final degree of reduction of the catalysts, the materials obtained after calcination were analyzed by H2-TPR, and the results are included in Fig. 3 . As expected, there was no measurable H2 consumption in the treatment of ZrO2 (Table S4), suggesting that the support was not significantly reduced under these conditions. The main peak at 78 °C for 5%Rh is associated with the reduction of Rh2O3 to Rh0 [51]. The integration of the peak suggests that the reduction is almost complete (Table S4). After addition of the second metal, the amount of H2 increases, which proves partial reduction of the second metal. 5%Rh-4%Re displayed a broad shoulder associated with hydrogen consumption centered at 175 °C which can be ascribed to the reduction of rhenium oxide [11,13,25]. For 5%Rh-4%W and 5%Rh-4%Mo there is no apparent shoulder. Therefore, the presence of metallic Rh promotes the reduction of Re2O7, WO3 and MoO3 due to H2 spillover. The results suggest that the Rh and the second metal (Re, W, Mo) are close, within spillover distance. The quantities of H2 consumed during the TPR indicate that Rh2O3 is fully reduced to Rh metal and that most of Re2O7 is reduced to Re metal (90%). Regarding Rh-W and Rh-Mo, there is partial reductions to WO3-x (with × ≈ 2) and MoO3-x (with × ≈ 1). The reduction to ca. MoIV agrees with previous literature [11]. These results show that the oxides exist as isolated monomers or oligomers (MoOx, WOx), in agreement with Raman spectroscopy, and suggest the possible formation of Mo-O-Zr and W-O-Zr bonds. Based on the TPR analyses, a treatment at 300 °C is enough to reduce Rh2O3. However, it was reported that a treatment near 500 °C improved Rh dispersion and thermal stability [52] which can limit the leaching of the second metal (e.g. W [16]). For the samples reduced at 100 °C, Rh should be fully reduced while the second metal will only be partially reduced. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on the catalysts after passivation and exposition to air. The Rh 3d spectra of the four representative systems are displayed in Figure S12 and the binding energies are shown in Table S5. The monometallic 5%Rh catalyst exhibits a sole doublet associated with Rh0 metal (BE = 307.6 eV), hence the rhodium is fully reduced [54]. This value varies between 307.5 and 308.0 eV after incorporation of the second metal and reduction at 450 °C, which remains within spectral resolution (0.5 eV) (Table S5). The bimetallic systems 5%Rh-4%Re, 5%Rh-4%W and 5%Rh-4%Mo exhibit a second peak (BE = 309.0–309.7 eV) characteristic of Rh3+ [54]. The distributions of the Rh oxidation states are included in Table S6. The results show that Rh is not fully reduced in presence of a second metal. The amount of Rh3+ increases with an increase of the molar ratio M/Rh (based on ICP; Table S6). This is due to oxydo-reduction phenomenon, with partial oxidation of Rh0 associated with partial reduction of Mo6+ cations. This is consistent with the results observed by Raman spectroscopy. This can only occur when there is close interaction between both metals. The proportion of Rh3+ depends on the nature of the second metal, following the order: Mo > W > Re. As expected, the temperature of reduction (100 °C, 450 °C, 700 °C) affects the degree of reduction of Rh: the proportion of Rh3+ decreases with increasing temperature, from 65% to 36% for Rh-Mo, and from 42% to 0% for Rh-W. This is also associated with a shift of BE associated with Rh metal from 308.5 eV to 307.2 eV, i.e. presence of Rhδ+ at 100 °C. It is worth noting that 5%Rh-4%W-700 present only Rh0 at 700 °C while Rh3+ is still present in 5%Rh-4%Mo-700. These results suggest a close interaction between the two metals, following the order Rh-Mo > Rh-W > Rh-Re, in agreement with the TPR results. The molar ratio M/Rh obtained by XPS are consistent, but slightly superior to those obtained by ICP (Table S6); hence, the second metal M might cover partially the Rh. The spectra associated with the second metal (Re 3f, W 4f and Mo 3d) are depicted in Figure S13 and the binding energies are included in Table S5. For Rh-Re (Figure S13a), the species Re6+ (Re 4f7/2, BE = 44.9 eV) [55] and Re7+ (Re 4f7/2, BE = 46.6 eV) [55] are observed. If present in small quantities, partially reduced species such as Re4+ (BE = 42.5 eV) [55] would overlap with a satellite of Zr 4p. Similarly, for Rh-W (Figure S13b), only W6+ (W 4f7/2, BE = 35.4 eV) [56] was observed. It is worth noting that reduced species such as W5+ (BE = 34.5 eV) [56] or W4+ (BE = 32.8 eV) [56] would also partially overlap with Zr 4p. Therefore, the absence of these species cannot be assessed with certainty. For Rh-Mo (Figure S13c), the peaks associated with Mo6+ (Mo 3d 5/2, BE = 232.8 eV) and Mo5+ (BE = 231.5 eV) were present [57,58]. No contributions assigned to more reduced species [57], such as Mo4+ (BE = 230.2 eV) or Mo0 (BE = 228.0 eV) could be observed. The presence of oxidized Re, W and Mo species is consistent with the oxophilic character of theses metals. Even if they were partially reduced during the reduction at 450 °C, the passivation treatment followed by exposure to air generates almost complete reoxidation. Regarding the samples reduced at 700 °C, an additional peak associated with W5+ (32%) was present for 5%Rh-4%W-700 (Table S5). The acidity bearing by the second metal may play a role on the performances of the catalysts. Indeed, some of the literature focused on selective C-O hydrogenolysis has reported the presence of acid sites on the bimetallic catalysts. The acidity was linked to the presence of ReOx, MoOx and WOx. For example, 4%Rh-ReOx/C has been shown to exhibit a peak around 225 °C, in contrast to the monometallic Rh/C which did not exhibit any acidity [13]. For Ni-WOx/SiO2 the amount of acidity increased with W content and WO3 surface density [20]. At low coverage, only Lewis acidity due to monotungstate WOx was present; at higher density, polytungstate surface species were formed and associated with Brønsted acid sites. Similarly, the acidity of Pt/WOx/Al2O3 was evaluated by FTIR of adsorbed pyridine. They observed that Brønsted acid sites resulted from the presence of polytungstates at high tungsten surface density (3.9 atoms nm2) [59]. It is known that the water plays a crucial role on the activity of these bimetallic catalysts. It has been shown that the conversion rate of THFA increases with the amount of water [14]. Moreover, a switch of solvent from water to dioxane or heptane is associated with a decrease in reaction rates and switch of transformation towards dehydration reactions [20,60]. It was proposed that Lewis acidity favor dehydration reactions while Brønsted acidity favor C-O hydrogenolysis, respectively [20]. Finally, it was suggested that, in the presence of water, Mo-OH or W-OH act as Brønsted sites and helps to stabilize the transition species. Thus, it is crucial to assess the acidity of the catalysts in the presence of water. In aqueous media the adsorption is accompanied by complex phenomena. Some of the acid sites, depending on their strength, can react with water, thus altering their activity towards the probe. The active sites are covered by water which has to be removed before the probe molecule can be retained by the solid. Therefore, the acidity of 5% Rh-based mono and bimetallic catalysts were characterized in aqueous phase using calorimetric measurements of 2-phenyl-ethylamine (PEA) adsorption. The screening of the surface acid sites in water leads to the effective acidity determination, in contrary to analyses in gas phase. This method allows not only to determine in liquid phase the total amount of acidic sites present on the catalyst but also shows the strength of these acidic sites. The heats evolved as a result of PEA adsorption are regarded as a measure of the ability of studied samples to maintain some acidity when suspended in water (polar compound with solvating ability) (Figure S14 and Fig. 4 a). For the first doses, corresponding to the highest acidic sites, the evolved heat decreases from 1.4 to 0.7 J g−1 following the order: 5%Rh-4%Re ≈ 5%Rh-4%W > 5%Rh-4%Mo > 5%Rh ≈ ZrO2. Since the evolved heat is a sum of two contributions with opposite signs (exothermic: adsorption enthalpy and endothermic: enthalpy of displacement of the solvent), this result can be explained by both a low effective acidity of the catalysts in water and a high enthalpy of displacement on water molecules. When comparing the behavior of bimetallic catalysts, except for the first injections, the calorimetric titration curve for Rh-Re always lies above that of Rh-W and the difference between the two curves increases as the titration progresses further (Fig. 4a). It means that the main difference between Rh-Re and Rh-W surfaces has to be ascribed to the medium and week strength acid sites. The calorimetric curve of 5%Rh-4%Mo is below those collected for Rh-Re and Rh-W samples and the evolved heats decreases more steeply toward low values. The integral heats of adsorption of PEA and the total amount of PEA introduced in order to attain an experimental heat of 0.4 J g−1are included in Fig. 4b. The integral heats reflect the total heat evolved from the sample when contacted by a given amounts of PEA, i.e. the adsorption strength of the active sites. The amounts of PEA introduced are representative of the total number of acidic sites per samples and shows that the adsorption capacity follows the same trend as the active site strength: Rh-Re ≈ Rh-W > Rh-Mo > Rh ≈ ZrO2. To conclude, the support ZrO2 exhibits low acidity which is not modified after addition of Rh. However, the incorporation of the second metal results in a strong increase of the amount and strength of the acidity. While the acidity of some of the catalysts tested for the hydrogenolysis of THFA have already been assessed by TPD of ammonia [10,13,14,20,22–24] or FTIR of adsorbed pyridine [19,20,22] we could not find any other report in the literature that provides measure of acidity by adsorption of a probe molecule in water. The results obtained by adsorption of PEA proved that the addition of the second metal introduces the acidic character of the catalysts in solvents of high polarity, like water, to a different extent depending on the nature of this metal. 3.2 Catalytic hydrogenolysis of THFA All the catalysts were tested under the same reaction conditions. First, a blank reaction was conducted without catalyst, with an aqueous solution of THFA (5 wt%) at 120 °C, under 80 bar of H2, for 24 h·THFA is highly stable under these reaction conditions and no conversion (<1%) was observed. A screening of several bimetallic systems was done (Figure S15 and Table S7) in an attempt to replace Rh which is an expensive metal. No conversion was observed with the systems based on non-noble metals (Co-Mo, Co-W, Cu-Mo, Cu-W, Ni-Mo, Ni–W). Pt was evaluated as alternative to Rh; Pt-Mo exhibited the best result with 8% of conversion after 24 h. As expected from previous literature [7,16,17], the results associated with Co-M, Cu-M, Ni-M and Pt-M (with M = W or Mo) confirmed the necessity of employing Rh as metal for the elaboration of catalysts active for the hydrogenolysis of THFA. The temporal evolutions of the concentrations of THFA and the products are included in Fig. 5 for 5%Rh, 5%Rh-4%Re, 5%Rh-4%W and 5%Rh-4%Mo. Selective C-O bond scission occurs and 1,5-pentanediol is the main product whatever the catalyst; 1-pentanol and 1-butanol are formed in small amounts (maximum combined selectivity below 35%). 1,2-pentanediol, 2-methyltetrahydrofuran, tetrahydrofuran, tetrahydropyran and 2-pentanol have never been observed, i.e. if any, the concentrations were below the detection limits (yield < 0.1%). The absence of formation of 1,2-pentanediol during the reaction is consistent with previous literature on Ir-M/SiO2 (M = Re, W, Mo), Rh-M/SiO2 (M = Re, W, Mo) and Pt/WO3/ZrO2 [7–11,19]. The mass balances were always above 95% and consistent with the TOC, hence all the products were quantified and no products were in the gas phase. A second batch of 5%Rh-4%Mo was synthesized and tested under the same reaction conditions. The results confirmed a really good reproducibility of the preparation and catalytic results when the catalysts are freshly prepared (X: 90% vs 90%, S1,5-PDO: 89% vs. 90%). For all the catalysts reduced at 450 °C, the conversion and the selectivity after 24 h are included in Table 2 . In order to evaluate the efficiency of the different catalysts, the initial rates were estimated and expressed per mass of Rh (VRh, mmolTHFA gRh −1h−1, Table 2) or second metal M (VM, mmolTHFA gM −1h−1, Table 2). While the monometallic catalysts (Rh) are hardly active, the incorporation of a second oxophilic metal increased the conversion and initial rates. When looking at the effect of the metal’s loadings, it appears that the conversion and initial rates are principally linked to the Rh content (Fig. 6 ), and to some extend to the loading of the second metal (Fig. 7 ). The influence of Re is much more pronounced in comparison to W and Mo. With 3% of Rh, Re-based catalysts are the most efficient in term of conversion and initial rates. At higher loading of Rh, 5%Rh-4%Mo is the best system with 90% conversion after 24 h. It is reported that the metals ratio affects the catalytic results where the conversion and yields of 1,5-PDO usually follow a volcano shape, with a maximum depending on the nature of the metals [7,9,17,19,23]. For example, for Pt-W system, when the amount of W is increased, the quantity of Brønsted sites between WO3 and the support increases (W-OH-Zr) [19]. However, when the amount of the second metal is above the monolayer, it must cover the metal sites which decreases the activity [23]. It was also reported for WOx/ZrO2 that the ratio Brønsted/Lewis acid sites increases with the tungsten loading [61,62]. In the present study, the yields of 1,5-PDO did not follow a volcano shape when increasing the molar ratio nM/nRh of 3%Rh-M/ZrO2 (Fig. 8 ). However, the catalysts exhibit surface coverages of 1–2 atoms nm−2 which are below the theoretical monolayer (around 4–5 atoms nm−2) [28,63]. The effect of W is more pronounced than with Re or Mo. Some samples based on 5%Rh-4%M were reduced at 100 °C or 700 °C in order to assess the effect of reduction temperature (Table S8). At 700 °C, the higher temperature must favor the complete reduction of Rh and the second metal, nevertheless this is accompanied by a decrease in the surface area of the support (Table S2). The thermal treatment can also affect the acidity of the catalyst. For example, WO3 exhibits Lewis acidity associated with W6+cations; a treatment of reduction allows an increase in acid site concentration and the formation of Brønsted acidity through the reduction of W6+ to lower valence states [64,65]. Regarding the conversion, it seems that 450 °C is the optimum temperature of reduction for Rh-W and Rh-Mo. For 5%Rh-4%Re-700, the conversion increased slightly when the sample is reduced at 700 °C but it is in detriment of the selectivity towards 1,5-PDO. Considering successive reactions (Scheme 1), selectivity depends to some extent on the conversion. For each bimetallic family (Rh-Re, Rh-W, Rh-Mo), the selectivity obtained at different conversions are combined in Fig. 9 . The linear trends obtained for the different systems suggest that the selectivity towards the three products does not depend on the reaction time, neither on the metals ratio, nor on the temperature of reduction of the catalysts. However, the nature of the second metal is crucial. The selectivity towards 1,5-pentanediol is less affected when Mo is the second metal since we reached 90% selectivity at almost complete conversion. On the other hand, in the presence of Rh-Re or Rh-W catalysts, the selectivity decreased down to 75 and 70%, respectively. Whatever the second metal, the main by-product is 1-pentanol (up to 25%) followed by smaller amount of 1-butanol (<15%). The hydrogenolysis of 1,5-PDO is known to generate 1-pentanol in high selectivity [19]. Numerous studies have reported the formation of butanol as traces but without giving details of its origin. Two studies proposed that the formation of butanol occur through C-O bond hydrogenolysis of THF on Ni catalysts [21,22]. However, we did not observe any THF during the reactions. Moreover, no conversion was observed over 5%Rh-4%Mo starting from THF as substrate. The absence of reactivity of THF confirms that the hydroxyl group of THFA is essential for the reactivity of the substrate through its adsorption on the surface, as reported elsewhere [19]. It was shown elsewhere, that 2-butanol is generated via decarbonylation of 1,4-pentanediol, during ү-valerolactone hydrogenation [66]. A reaction was conducted from 1,5-PDO with 5%Rh-4%Mo where POL (yield of 10%) and BOL (yield of 4%) were obtained as the only products after 24 h, under the same reaction conditions as previously. The mass balance was of 100% at the end of the reaction, thus no products such as pentane or butane were formed in gas phase. This result suggests that BOL might be formed via decarbonylation of 1,5-PDO. As observed in Fig. 9, the selectivities achieved with Rh-Re and Rh-W based catalysts at high conversion are significantly lower in comparison to those achieved with Rh-Mo based catalysts. Therefore, the catalysts with the highest number of acid sites (Fig. 4) favor the successive reactions and formation of pentanol and butanol, following the order: Rh-Re ≈ Rh-W > Rh-Mo > Rh. The results obtained by TPR, Raman spectroscopy, CO chemisorption and TEM show the presence of small nanoparticles of Rh (≈ 2 nm) in close proximity of the second metal. Moreover, molybdenum, tungsten and rhenium oxides are present as monomers or two-dimensional oligomers. There is a close interaction between the metals, following the order: Rh-Mo > Rh-W > Rh-Re. This can be directly correlated to the catalytic results, where 5%Rh-4%Mo exhibit the highest conversion and productivity (Table 2). To conclude on the active sites, this work proved the bifunctional properties of the catalysts, where the Rh particles bring the metallic active sites, while the second metal generates some Brønsted acidity·THFA is adsorbed on the surface through –CH2OH group on the Brønsted acid sites (e.g. Zr-M−OH) (Scheme 2 ). H2 is dissociated on the noble metal (Rh0) and atoms of hydrogen then attack the C-O bond. According to the XPS analyses, Rh3+ is present on the surface of the catalysts after passivation and exposure to air. During the catalytic reaction at 120 °C under H2, this species should be reduced based on TPR analyses. Moreover, EXAFS analyzes carried out on Rh-ReOx/SiO2 and Rh-MoOx/SiO2 showed that Rh presents a metallic structure after THFA hydrogenolysis reaction [11]. A close proximity between the active sites increases the conversion. Finally, the selectivity is linked to the acidity where a medium acidity is necessary for the formation of 1,5-pentanediol however stronger acidity favors successive reactions and formation of secondary products. The best results are obtained with 5%Rh-4%Mo/ZrO2 which generates 81% of 1,5-pentanediol and 7% of 1-pentanol, with a productivity of 47 mmolPDO gcata −1. This value is in the same range of those reported in the literature [8,9,12,15]. The productivity of 1,5-pentanediol follow the order: Mo > W > Re. Our results do not follow exactly the same trend as for Rh-M/SiO2 where Re > Mo > W [9]. This might be due to the difference of support which affect the metal-support interaction (Zr-M−OH), hence the Brønsted acidity. Metal leaching is known to occur during hydrogenolysis of THFA, therefore ICP analyzes of the solutions were carried out at the end of the reaction. When using 5%Rh-4%Re and 5%Rh-4%W, some Re and W were present in the solution indicating partial leaching (<5%), in agreement with previous literature [20,25]. Subsequent washing of the solid under air might generate even more leaching of the metals, hence these catalysts were not recycled. It is worth noting that for 5%Rh-4%Mo, the amount of Rh and Mo in solution at the end of the reaction was below the detection limit, indicating that the leaching is below 0.1% of the initial amount of metals. Moreover, the support is stable, as no Zr was detected in solution. After reaction, 5%Rh-4%Mo was recovered by filtration and reused directly, without any pretreatment. Unfortunately, the conversion decreased from ca. 90% to 51% (Table S9). Deactivation was already reported elsewhere for this reaction [7,17,19], and mainly attributed to metal leaching and to some extent to metal growth. With Rh-Mo system, there was no metal leaching and the XRD and the XPS did not show any noticeable changes (Table S6). 3.3 Kinetic study To study the kinetics of the THFA hydrolysis, 12 experiments were performed with 2 batches of 5%Rh-4%Mo catalyst, varying the substrate, the initial concentrations of the substrate (0–500 mmol L−1), the hydrogen partial pressure (20–80 bar) and the temperature of the reaction (90–120 °C). The reactions conditions and catalytic results are included in Table S10 and Figure S16.Then, a known amount of either 1,5-PDO, POL, or BOL was added with THFA from the start of the reaction (under standard conditions) and no inhibition was observed. In a first approach, a first-order law towards all the reactants was considered and only the experiments at 120 °C using a “freshly prepared” catalyst (<one month) were used (tests 1–7, Table S10). As 2-methyltetrahydrofuran and 1,2-pentanediol were never observed under our reaction conditions, they were not included in the kinetic study. The rate constant k1, k2, k3, k4 and k5 associated with hydrogenolysis reactions in Scheme 1 were studied. The following expression (eq. (4) was used for each reaction, resulting in a system of 5 equations and 5 unknown parameters. (4) r i = k i ∙ [ r e a c t a n t ] ∙ [ H 2 ] ∙ m c a t a With [reactant] and [H2] the concentration of reactant and H2 in the solution (mol L−1); mcata the mass of catalyst (g); the rate ri (mmol L−1) and the rate constant ki (L2 mmol−1 gcata −1 s−1) are associated with the step i (i = 1 to 5), t (reaction time, s). Using the experimental data points (Table S10, Figure S16), the estimated parameters are the following: k1 = 110.10−5 ± 6.10−5 L2 mmol−1 gcata −1 s−1 k2 = 13.10−5 ± 2.10−5 L2 mmol−1 gcata −1 s−1 k3 = 1.6.10−5 ± 0.1.10−5 L2.mmol−1 gcata −1 s−1 k4 = 140.10−5 ± 20.10−5 L2 mmol−1 gcata −1 s−1 k5 = 10.10−5 ± 4.10−5 L2 mmol−1 gcata −1 s−1 The results show that that k1 > k2 > k3, with k1/k2 = 8 and k1/k3 = 68. This is consistent with analyzed products observed during reaction. Indeed, 1,5-PDO is the major primary product. Following stepwise reactions, it is then slowly converted to POL and, to a lower extent, BOL as secondary products. k4 and k5 are in the same order of magnitude as k1 and k2, respectively. Therefore, if high quantity of POL and BOL were formed, it is likely that further hydrogenolysis will occur and butane and pentane will appear in gas phase. The carbon balance based on the TOC analyses were above 95%, hence these last reactions hardly occur. This must be due to the low concentration of POL and BOL at the end of the reactions. The addition of 1,5-PDO at the beginning of the reaction did not impact the reaction. This shows that when there is competitive adsorption between THFA and 1,5-PDO, THFA is more strongly bonded to the surface. This explain the lower reactivity of 1,5-PDO in presence of THFA and the high selectivity to 1,5-PDO obtained with this catalyst. The results confirm the applicability of a first order law towards THFA concentration and H2. Some kinetic data were previously reported over Rh-ReOx/SiO2 and Ir-ReOx/SiO2 under similar reaction conditions (80 bar, 120 °C) but with more concentrated solution of THFA (20–60 wt% vs 5 wt%) [10,12]. A reaction order of one was obtained for H2, however an order of zero with respect to THFA concentration was reported. These results suggest that the interaction between THFA and the catalyst might be weaker for Rh-Mo/ZrO2 (in this study) than Ir-ReOx/SiO2 or Rh-ReOx/SiO2. Considering now more precisely the experimental concentration profiles, it appears that an induction period is visible and that a refined model should be considered to better fit the experimental data for the catalysts stored for a long time (example in Figure S17). Indeed, after synthesis the catalyst is passivated, stored and used in catalytic reactions without any further pretreatment. Hence, this induction period corresponds to the reduction of the catalyst in the reactor, when H2 is added. Equation (eq. (5) is added to consider this activation phenomenon (ractivation). (5) r a c t i v a t i o n = k a c t i v a t i o n ∙ m c a t a ∙ [ H 2 ] The catalyst was found to deactivate, and this occurred according to two mechanisms. First, a deactivation can occur during the time (t) of the batch experiments. This deactivation depends on the mass of catalyst. Another deactivation is due to ageing of the catalytic powder between the synthesis and the catalytic test (age in days). Equation (eq. (6) proposes to include these deactivation modes. (6) r T H F A = k 1 ∙ [ T H F A ] ∙ [ H 2 ] ∙ m c a t a ∙ e - k ′ ∙ t ∙ m cata n ∙ e - k " ∙ a g e For the four secondary reactions, the following equation was used: (7) r i = k i ∙ [ r e a c t a n t i ] ∙ [ H 2 ] ∙ m c a t a Considering also the effect of temperature: (8) k i = k i , 0 ∙ e - E a / R T Thus, all the data obtained during the 12 experiments in batch reactor, representing a total of 388 data points, were used to estimate the kinetic parameters. Due to the high number of parameters describing the new system (14 parameters), identifying them independently was not possible however, all the possible solutions give a ratio k1/k2 of 8 and k1/k3 of 43, really close to those obtained in first approximation. Even if numerical values of all the parameters cannot be provided, the equations were found to describe appropriately the entire set of experiments, as shown by the parity plot representing the 388 concentrations (Fig. 10 ). An activation energy of 68 ± 4 kJ mol−1 was estimated. This is of the same order of magnitude as what was reported for the C-O hydrogenolysis of erythritol over Ir-ReOx/TiO2 (Ea = 79 kJ mol−1) [18]. The estimated concentrations associated with the different reactions are included in Figure S16. As an example, the 2 experiments conducted with the standard reaction conditions, where the catalyst was employed either 2 days or 44 days after synthesis are shown in Fig. 11 . The model was found to consider the activation of the catalyst, the deactivation during the run, and the 42 days ageing. 4 Conclusion To summarize, bimetallic Rh-based catalysts exhibited very high selectivity in the hydrogenolysis of THFA to 1,5-PDO. Re, W and Mo were evaluated as the second metal and it was shown that Mo was the most efficient in the considered reaction. The characterizations of the bimetallic catalysts have confirmed that small nanoparticles of Rh and MOx (M = Re, W, Mo) were prepared regardless the nature of the metals. TPR analysis, CO chemisorption and XPS spectroscopy revealed higher interaction between Mo and Rh compared to the other oxides. Furthermore, microcalorimetry in liquid phase has shown that acidity character of Rh-Mo catalysts is less pronounced than Rh-Re and Rh-W. Thanks to this moderate acidity, Rh-Mo catalysts exhibited almost constant selectivity towards 1,5-PDO regardless the conversion of THFA which allowed to reach up to 81% yield of 1,5-PDO using 5%Rh-4%Mo/ZrO2 catalyst. These bimetallic catalysts are very promising to achieve selective hydrogenolysis of biobased substrates, however further works are under progress to optimize the stability of these systems. coredata.dc:description: The hydrogenolysis of tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol was studied in aqueous phase over a range of bifunctional catalysts based on Rh and an oxophilic promoter (Re, W, Mo) supported on ZrO2. The structures of the catalysts were characterised employing powder XRD, Raman spectroscopy and TEM analysis. The degrees of reduction were evaluated by H2-TPR and XPS analyses. The metallic properties were assessed by CO chemisorption. For the first time, the acidic properties were evaluated in aqueous phase by calorimetric measurements of 2-phenyl-ethylamine adsorption heat. The combination of metallic Rh sites and Brønsted sites (linked to the oxophilic metal on ZrO2) is crucial for the reaction. The bifunctionality of the catalysts was demonstrated and up to 81% yield of 1,5-pentanediol is obtained with 5%Rh-4%Mo/ZrO2.

coredata.dc:title: Investigation of the bifunctionality of catalysts based on Rh associated with an oxophilic promoter in the hydrogenolysis of tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol to 1,5-pentanediol
